info.game_comments: Battle of the Decades quarterfinal game 1.

(1, 1).clue: His papacy lasted just over a month in 1978

(1, 3).clue: Israeli forces destroyed Egypt's air force on the ground on June 5, 1967, the first day of this war

(2, 5).clue: William S. Burroughs' first published book

(6, 5).clue: It's the Shawnee word for what we call an elk

(1, 1).clue: In 1687 this Brit differentiated "absolute, true, and mathematical time" & "relative, apparent, and common time"

(2, 1).clue: A food lover & avid gardener, Edmund McIlhenny created this sauce from plants that he cultivated himself

(3, 1).clue: "Le Sacre du printemps" is the French title of this Stravinsky ballet that premiered in Paris in 1913

(4, 1).clue: If someone calls you "cray", he has left this letter out of another word

(1, 2).clue: This 18th century German's "critique" of time? It's "phenomenally real" but "noumenally unreal"

(2, 2).clue: Brace yourself! Edward Angle was the modern father of this branch of dentistry

(3, 2).clue: The libretto for a ballet about this title gladiator was based in part on works by Plutarch

(4, 2).clue: "Skrilla" refers to this; the DJ Skrillex must have tons of it

(1, 3).clue: An 1884 conference chose the meridian of this facility's transit instrument as the "prime" starting point for time zones

(2, 3).clue: With a mark of 5'6" in this event, in 1948 5'7" Alice Coachman became the first African-American woman to win Olympic gold

(3, 3).clue: At the end of a Mozart opera, this title character is dragged into the flames of hell

(1, 4).clue: Following Einstein, in 1908 Hermann Minkowski proposed the idea of 4-dimensional this hyphenated term

(3, 4).clue: At the end of this Verdi opera, Violetta dies of consumption in the arms of Alfredo

(5, 4).clue: On the Ubangi River, Bangui is the capital of this 3-word nation

(1, 5).clue: Clocks flown around the Earth in 1971 diverged from stationary ones, confirming the relativity concept "time" this

(3, 5).clue: In a classic ballet by Adolphe Adam, she's the title peasant girl with a weak heart & a passion for dancing

(0, 0).clue: This word for a timid person comes from the last name of a character in a 1920s newspaper comic called "The Timid Soul"
